meanings.definition: A stock character in commedia dell'arte, typically portrayed as a boastful coward or buffoon.
meanings.sent1: In the play, the scaramouche always made everyone laugh with his silly antics.
meanings.sent2: The scaramouche strutted around the stage, pretending to be brave but actually quite scared.
meanings.sent3: The scaramouche tried to act tough, but his friends knew he was just putting on a show.
meanings.sent4: Her little brother was a scaramouche, always talking big but running away when things got tough.
meanings.sent5: The scaramouche's exaggerated gestures and funny expressions delighted the audience.

meanings.sent1: Don't pay attention to that scaramouche; he's all talk and no action.
meanings.sent2: The scaramouche boasted about his achievements, but deep down, he was afraid of failure.
meanings.sent3: Despite his scaramouche behavior, he was actually quite kind and helpful to those in need.
meanings.sent4: She saw through his scaramouche facade and knew he was just trying to cover up his insecurities.
meanings.sent5: The scaramouche's constant bragging annoyed everyone around him.

meanings.definition: To behave in a boastful or cowardly manner.
meanings.sent1: He would scaramouche around, pretending to be tough when he was actually scared.
meanings.sent2: She scaramouched her way through the challenge, talking big but avoiding any real action.
meanings.sent3: When faced with a difficult decision, he would often scaramouche to avoid taking responsibility.
meanings.sent4: The politician tried to scaramouche his way out of answering the tough questions.
meanings.sent5: Instead of facing his fears, he chose to scaramouche his way out of the situation.
